title: 105_s1681
content: Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include voluntary advertising limits and benefits for eligible congressional candidates. The section defines terms related to campaign advertising, eligible congressional candidates, general election period, and primary election period. The primary election period is defined as starting 30 days before the primary election and ending on the date of the election. A candidate must meet filing requirements certified by the Commission for both the primary and general elections to be considered eligible for election to the Senate or House of Representatives. The primary election filing requirement states that a candidate must file a declaration with the Commission stating they will only participate in campaign advertising during the primary election period and that at least one other candidate has qualified for the same primary election ballot. The deadline for filing this declaration is before the primary election date. The general election filing requirement states that a candidate must file a declaration with the Commission stating they will not participate in campaign advertising except during the general election period. The deadline for filing this declaration is 7 days after the candidate qualifies for the general election ballot. If an eligible congressional candidate has an opponent who qualifies for the ballot, they are entitled to broadcast media rates under the Communications Act of 1934. The candidate must use this benefit for communication purposes. The Commission will certify if a candidate meets the requirements for broadcast media rates under the Communications Act of 1934. Certification for primary election candidates must be done within 7 business days of filing a declaration. The Commission certifies candidates for broadcast media rates under the Communications Act of 1934. Certification for primary election candidates must be done within 7 business days of filing a declaration. The Commission can revoke certification if a candidate violates any requirements of the section. The Commission can revoke certification for candidates who violate requirements, making them ineligible for further benefits under this section. Any misuse of benefits will result in the candidate having to repay the provider. Commission determinations are final unless subject to judicial review. Candidates who misuse benefits will have to repay the provider an amount equal to the difference in cost between what they paid and what they would have paid if not an eligible congressional candidate. SEC. 2. BROADCAST RATES AND PREEMPTION. Broadcast Rates amendment under Section 315(b) of the Communications Act of 1934 includes changes to charges and rates for broadcast media. This involves adjustments to margins, reducing the charge from forty-five to 30, and specifying the lowest charge for the same amount of time on the same date. The amendment under Section 315(b) of the Communications Act of 1934 modifies charges for broadcast media. It limits charges for eligible congressional candidates to 50% of the lowest charge, and excludes non-eligible candidates from this provision. The amendment under Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 addresses preemption of broadcasting station use by eligible congressional candidates who have purchased advertising spots. The amendment under Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 addresses preemption of broadcasting station use by eligible congressional candidates who have purchased advertising spots. The license of a broadcasting station may be revoked for failure to permit access to a candidate's advertising spot, with the amendments taking effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act.
